comments:
I got this secondhand from a developer. We had no internet connectivity at the time (had internal lan connectivity, though) due to some issue at our provider. Developer selected "Generate getters and setters" from the context menu in a source editor and experienced an Eclipse crash (app closed down). On subsequent invocation of this command, there was no problem and the dialog window appeared. The logged information was the following:

eclipse.buildId=M20070921-1145
java.version=1.6.0_02
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_CA Framework arguments:  -showlocation -Xms512m -Xmx512m -XX:PermSize=256m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m Command-line arguments:  -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86 -clean -showlocation -Xms512m -Xmx512m -XX:PermSize=256m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m

More information:
the exception should nut be passed though, and also not logged.

The crash is completely unrelated to the log entry. Can you reproduce the crash?

JDT Text needs to know more details about the JavaModelException (code) i.e. is it because the URL couldn't be reached or timed out or is it an internal error (e.g. corrupt format) that we need to log.

Also, the log message should contain the URL that was tried to access. This information is currently not visible in the .log.

NOTE: when I tried to reproduce using an invalid URL (e.g. use son instead of sun in the URL) I got an "Unknown javadoc format" exception. Instead I would have expected an exception that says file/url not found. Do you want a separate bug for that?


!ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.ui 4 10001 2007-10-23 10:37:16.204
!MESSAGE Internal Error

Java Model Exception: Java Model Status [Unknown javadoc format for Object [in Object.class [in org.omg.CORBA [in C:\JavaSDKs\jdk1.5.0_10\jre\lib\rt.jar]]]]

!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.jdt.core 4 1009 2007-10-23 10:37:16.214
!MESSAGE Unknown javadoc format for Object [in Object.class [in org.omg.CORBA [in C:\JavaSDKs\jdk1.5.0_10\jre\lib\rt.jar]]]

As I mentioned, I reported this secondhand as caused by a temporary condition, but recall that our network was down completely going out (we likely didn't even have DNS working internally due to the way things are set up here). The UnknownHostException was thrown because the name "java.sun.com" could not be resolved. This type of outage is not that common since in most cases when Internet connectivity is lost on a corporate LAN, you still have DNS name resolution from a cache, at least.
